column1: Legal Services for Prisoners with Children
column3: LSPC organizes communities impacted by the criminal justice system and advocates to release incarcerated people, to restore human and civil rights, and to reunify families and communities. We build public awareness of structural racism in policing, the courts, and the prison system, and we advance racial and gender justice in all our work.
column4: Useful handout that includes form for "petition for release" for prisoners who are at-risk: https://prisonerswithchildren.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Coronavirus-CA-Jails.pdf

column3: The mission of BOSS is to help homeless, poor, and disabled people achieve health and self-sufficiency, and to fight against the root causes of poverty and homelessness. Also helps former incarcerated people get back on their feet.

column1: Community Legal Services of East Palo Alto
column3: Provides free legal services to low-income clients throughout the region. CLSEPA provides help for tenants facing evictions or rent increases, living in unhealthy or unsafe homes, or experiencing harrassment or discrimination by landlords. CLSEPA also has a rescue housing fund for individuals who need emergency assistance.
column4: Call 650-326-6440 for a phone intake with the housing rights clinic

column1: Bay Area Legal Aid Alameda County Tenant's Rights Line
column3: Hotline to help people protect low-income Alameda residents facing housing-related issues including illegal evictions, eviction after foreclosure; substandard housing conditions; and wrongful denials and terminations of housing subsidies.

column1: Catholic East Bay Charities Alameda County Support
column3: Catholic East Bay Charities provides housing services to eligibile Alameda county residents, including financial assistance and legal aid.
column5: Individuals and families living in Alameda County with more resources for those in Oakland; Seniors age 55 and older; Disabled individuals; Low to moderate income individuals and families with dependent children; Emancipated foster youth; Veterans; Victims of domestic violence or violent crimes; or Pregnant women in their second trimester.

column3: EBCLC’s Housing Program focuses on defending eviction lawsuits brought against low-income tenants.
column5: Low income tenants in Berkeley, Oakland, Emeryville, Alameda

column1: Catholic East Bay Charities Contra Costa County Support
column3: Catholic East Bay Charities provides housing services to eligibile Contra Costa county residents, including financial assistance and legal aid.

column3: Tenants’ Rights Program attorneys represent tenants with evictions in Alameda County. Tenants who have received unlawful detainers should call for an appointment immediately. Tenants will be given the first appointment available.
column5: Low income tenants in Alameda County, except those living in Berkeley, Emeryville or Albany

column3: A hotline to help recently incarcerated individuals readjust to society. Monday - Thursday, emergency only. Friday, non-emergency.

column3: Can assist with navigating registering for health insurance (MediCal and CalFresh)

column3: Qualificatioins for Medi-Cal Benefits
column5: Medi-Cal covers low-income adults, families with children, seniors, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, children in foster care and former foster youth up to age 26.

column3: Covered California is the state’s health insurance marketplace where Californians can shop for health plans and access financial assistance if they qualify for it.
column4: Call this number for assistance from a Certified Enroller who can assist you in picking a plan and receiving the maximum financial assistance available.

column3: Health Insurance Company Contact Information
You may qualify to enroll in a new healthcare plan because of a life event (like losing job, getting married, having child, moving, or losing your health insureance) for 60 days after the event.
column5: Special Enrollment is available for those who have had qualifying life events. Use this resource to see if you qualify.

column3: COBRA is a federal law that helps workers who lose their job or have their hours reduced continue their health insurance plan (usually 18 months).
column4: Insured person must still pay the premium and an administrative fee.
column5: Employer must have at least 20 employees to be eligible.

column3: Cal-COBRA is a California Law that lets you keep your group health plan when your job ends or your hours are reduced. It may also be available to people who have exhausted their Federal COBRA.
column5: Unlike federal COBRA, covers small employers (2 to 19 employees).

column3: Information on when an insurance company can cancel your health insurance.
Organizaiton providing the basics of choosing a healthcare plan, getting access to healthcare, and dealing with insurance companies.

column1: Patient Advocate Foundation's Co-Pay Relief Program
column3: The PAF Co-Pay Relief Program, one of the self-contained divisions of PAF, provides direct financial assistance to insured patients who meet certain qualifications to help them pay for the prescriptions and/or treatments they need. This assistance helps patients afford the out-of-pocket costs for these items that their insurance company requires.
A list of national and regional organizations with programs to assist patients in obtaining and affording healthcare.

column1: Patient Advocate Foundation's Case Management Service
column3: One-on-one personal advocate services to patients battling serious disease. Our staff helps seek out options to overcome insurance denials, healthcare access issues and medical debt crisis challenges.

HICAP (Health Insurance Counseling and Advocacy Program) provides free, confidential one-on-one counseling, education, and assistance to individuals and their families on Medicare, Long-Term Care insurance, other health insurance related issues, and planning ahead for Long-Term Care needs. HICAP also provides legal assistance or legal referrals in dealing with Medicare or Long-Term Care insurance related issues.
column5: Must be 65+, have a disability, or otherwise be eligible for medicare.

column3: Information on Disputing Debt Collectors
Health Consumer Center provides legal help associated with health care issues or unfair medical billing.
column4: Available in all languages.

column3: The Health Consumer Alliance (HCA) offers free assistance over-the-phone  to help people who are struggling to get or maintain health coverage and resolve problems with their health plans.
column4: Consultations are confidential.

column1: Independent Living Resources of Solano and Contra Costa Counties
column3: ILR provides information and education regarding fair housing laws, and can help you explore your options when it comes to renting or home ownership. ILR also provides help concerning other housing related issues, such as landlord/tenant issues, mediation, roommates (shared housing), and more.
column5: Must be a person with a disability

column1: Legal Aid at Work: Workers' Rights Disability Law Clinic

Both toll-free helplines and clinic appointments are available.
